gospel.text:
[[Mc 5,21]]When Jesus had crossed again in the boat to the other side, a large crowd gathered around him, and he stayed close to the sea.
[[Mc 5,22]]One of the synagogue officials, named Jairus, came forward. Seeing him he fell at his feet
[[Mc 5,23]]and pleaded earnestly with him, saying, "My daughter is at the point of death. Please, come lay your hands on her that she may get well and live."
[[Mc 5,24]]He went off with him, and a large crowd followed him and pressed upon him.
[[Mc 5,25]]There was a woman afflicted with hemorrhages for twelve years.
[[Mc 5,26]]She had suffered greatly at the hands of many doctors and had spent all that she had. Yet she was not helped but only grew worse.
[[Mc 5,27]]She had heard about Jesus and came up behind him in the crowd and touched his cloak.
[[Mc 5,28]]She said, "If I but touch his clothes, I shall be cured."
[[Mc 5,29]]Immediately her flow of blood dried up. She felt in her body that she was healed of her affliction.
[[Mc 5,30]]Jesus, aware at once that power had gone out from him, turned around in the crowd and asked, "Who has touched my clothes?"
[[Mc 5,31]]But his disciples said to him, "You see how the crowd is pressing upon you, and yet you ask, 'Who touched me?'"
[[Mc 5,32]]And he looked around to see who had done it.
[[Mc 5,33]]The woman, realizing what had happened to her, approached in fear and trembling. She fell down before Jesus and told him the whole truth.
[[Mc 5,34]]He said to her, "Daughter, your faith has saved you. Go in peace and be cured of your affliction."
[[Mc 5,35]]While he was still speaking, people from the synagogue official's house arrived and said, "Your daughter has died; why trouble the teacher any longer?"
[[Mc 5,36]]Disregarding the message that was reported, Jesus said to the synagogue official, "Do not be afraid; just have faith."
[[Mc 5,37]]He did not allow anyone to accompany him inside except Peter, James, and John, the brother of James.
[[Mc 5,38]]When they arrived at the house of the synagogue official, he caught sight of a commotion, people weeping and wailing loudly.
[[Mc 5,39]]So he went in and said to them, "Why this commotion and weeping? The child is not dead but asleep."
[[Mc 5,40]]And they ridiculed him. Then he put them all out. He took along the child's father and mother and those who were with him and entered the room where the child was.
[[Mc 5,41]]He took the child by the hand and said to her, "Talitha koum," which means, "Little girl, I say to you, arise!"
[[Mc 5,42]]The girl, a child of twelve, arose immediately and walked around. (At that) they were utterly astounded.
[[Mc 5,43]]He gave strict orders that no one should know this and said that she should be given something to eat.
gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Mark

first_reading.text:
[[2_S 18,9]]Absalom unexpectedly came up against David's servants. He was mounted on a mule, and, as the mule passed under the branches of a large terebinth, his hair caught fast in the tree. He hung between heaven and earth while the mule he had been riding ran off.
[[2_S 18,10]]Someone saw this and reported to Joab that he had seen Absalom hanging from a terebinth.
[[2_S 18,14b]]Joab replied, "I will not waste time with you in this way." And taking three pikes in hand, he thrust for the heart of Absalom, still hanging from the tree alive.
[[2_S 18,24]]Now David was sitting between the two gates, and a lookout mounted to the roof of the gate above the city wall, where he looked about and saw a man running all alone.
[[2_S 18,25a]]The lookout shouted to inform the king, who said, "If he is alone, he has good news to report." As he kept coming nearer,
[[2_S 18,30]]The king said, "Step aside and remain in attendance here." So he stepped aside and remained there.
[[2_S 18,31]]When the Cushite came in, he said, "Let my lord the king receive the good news that this day the LORD has taken your part, freeing you from the grasp of all who rebelled against you."
[[2_S 18,32]]But the king asked the Cushite, "Is young Absalom safe?" The Cushite replied, "May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rebel against you with evil intent be as that young man!"
[[2_S 19,1]]The king was shaken, and went up to the room over the city gate to weep. He said as he wept, "My son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!"
[[2_S 19,2]]Joab was told that the king was weeping and mourning for Absalom;
[[2_S 19,3]]and that day's victory was turned into mourning for the whole army when they heard that the king was grieving for his son.
first_reading.title: 2nd book of Samuel

psalm.text:
[[Ps 86,1]]Incline your ear, O LORD; answer me, 
for I am afflicted and poor.
[[Ps 86,2]]Keep my life, for I am devoted to you; 
save your servant who trusts in you.
[[Ps 86,3]]You are my God. 

Have mercy on me, O Lord, 
for to you I call all the day.
[[Ps 86,4]]Gladden the soul of your servant, 
for to you, O Lord, I lift up my soul.

[[Ps 86,5]]For you, O Lord, are good and forgiving, 
abounding in kindness to all who call upon you.
[[Ps 86,6]]Hearken, O LORD, to my prayer 
and attend to the sound of my pleading.
psalm.title: Psalms
